posts.content:
TBH, I have never really used Taunt before but it was available in a recent build I designed so any education would help me to maximize its effectiveness. Please recognize that at present I am unable to actually playtest, but would still like to understand the limitations of the skill from a building perspective. The questions (these arose because the wiki doesn't seem to clarify them):

1. Effective range? The phrase "aware of the taunter" means little to me. Is this another way of saying "within the perception range"? If so, then it seems as though Taunts can be activated from long range, no?

2. Spamming. Is there a cool-down? If so, what is it?

3. Re-rolls. If one spams Taunt, can a maximum dice roll value be achieved and sustained? Or will a poor roll "overwrite" a good one?

4. Since it is a combat action, it would break any hidden effects that spells such as Imp Inv or GS would provide. But is it even available while under the effects of those spells?

That should get me headed in the right direction.

So, as usual, thanks, in advance for the learning lesson. Contrary to popular belief, old dogs can indeed learn new tricks! *g*

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
I'm far from being a specialist, but I will give it a go anyhow.

1- Taunt requires that the target be aware of you to work, so that means that you can't taunt someone without being in combat with them. If you taunt a neutral creature, it will be considered a hostile action and if its an NPC, he/she will most likely attack.

2- You cannot SPAM Taunt, when you taunt someone, it takes a whole round to activate (meaning if you move or attack it will be interrupted) at the end of which it shows the result: either success or failure along with the opposed roll. Like this:

Taunt: Success X + Taunt modifier = Y, DC: Z. That DC is the opponent's concentration check, which you can use to get an idea if the opponent is even Tauntable. If the DC is too high for you, unless your roll was very low on your taunt check you shouldn't even try it again.

Regardless of success or failure, you have to refrain from using it for another full round after the result is out. Then after 6 seconds it becomes available again. When you rty to use it before these 6 seconds, a message will appear saying you can't use that skill: X seconds left or something like that.

One other common thing is to have your taunting interrupted by making an attack of opportunity. Whenever a Taunt is interrupted, the next time you try to taunt someone, it will be INSTANTANEOUS. I often use that to my advantage before tough melee bosses, I taunt a minion just prior to its death and then cancel before the result is out. Then I kill it and when I taunt the boss it comes out instantly. That can be very helpful, instead of standing in front of a very tough and very angry heavy hitting boss taunting him.

3- I don't know this one, but the correct thing is to not taunt someone that has already been successfully taunted. If you failed last time, then after a round you can try again like explained above. Does anyone happen to know this? I have never tried it myself. Say, if the difference between ur taunt and the opponent concentration checks is 2, hence you diminish their ac by 2, if you re-taunt him and get a result of 6 dis time, does the new penalty override the old one, or does the first one count how about if your result is 1, does it override or does the previous result count? I cant test it, but combat debugging should tell u that much. My keyboard doesn't consider tilde where its supposed to be because it's a brazilian keyboard so i cant enter the modes.

4- Like I said in 1, the target needs to be aware of you, so if you try to taunt anyone who isn't aware of you, a message will appear saying that. Kind of like Animal Empathy: Failure: target needs to be aware of you to use this ability.

5- I know you didn't ask anything about that, but I should mention this anyway for whoever wants to know. Taunt cancels all combat modes, so if you use power attack, expertise or flurry of blows, when the result comes in, you will need to reactivate the combat mode.

Hope this clarifies thing a bit

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content: Something fundamental to be aware of, while you taunt someone you are flatfooted. That's why if you have to taunt someone nasty it's better to do it while a companion or meatshield is keeping him busy or while the bad guy is prone or otherwise unable to hit you.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
KailPendragon wrote:Something fundamental to be aware of, while you taunt someone you are flatfooted. That's why if you have to taunt someone nasty it's better to do it while a companion or meatshield is keeping him busy or while the bad guy is prone or otherwise unable to hit you.
Also, it should be noted what being flat-footed means for those who don't know. You lose your DEX and Dodge bonuses to AC. Having the Uncanny Dodge feat, attainable by being Rogue 3, Barbarian 2, Assassin 2 or Shadowdancer 2, you retain the Dex bonus to AC even when flat-footed, losing only Dodge AC. In STR melee builds that go Full Plate / Shield, being flat-footed is of little importance, as they generally have +1 DEX AC and not too much dodge, except for those with Epic Mage Armor and Divine Shield, they can only get Dodge AC from boots. In regular NWN, a monk's boots +5 is as far as it goes. So if you Taunt with Expertise on with a meleer, you will effectively just lose 1 AC. If in a low magic environment, even less. However, Kail has some taunting Dragons, which gain their Dodge AC cap by shifting, so they really suffer when trying to taunt. You should know whether being flat-footed will be significant to your build and act accordingly.
